results.content:
First time with React, but I had a very bad impression.
Firstly you install many plugins, you spend one hour installing things, however there is a very simple command to create a react application which gives you everything, so you waste your time doing all this. Then you download resources for every chapter, but I have errors running all of them, no instructions to run them, so I couldn't run many of the sections.

response.content:
Francisco, it's sad to hear that the course didn't match your expectations. Nevertheless, I'd like to clarify a few things.

After the section about the basics of TypeScript, there are three sections about using TypeScript with React.

In the first one of these three we work on a simple app from scratch using webpack(the goal is to focus on the basics of using TypeScript with React and show how TypeScript is actually set up under the hood of such frameworks as Create React App and Next.js).

In the section that follows we're using Create React App(you mentioned a command to create a React app, I guess it’s the command you meant) and Redux. And in the last section we’re working with Next.js (a React framework that includes even more than Create React App, at least at this moment).

In each of these sections, in my opinion, I install the minimal amount of packages necessary for comfortable developer experience. I install each package only at the time when it’s necessary and I explain what that package is used for.

You said: "you spend one hour installing things". In my opinion, this statement is not true. Could you please explain this in more detail?

Finally, even though it’s mentioned in the course description I’d like to say that this course is most suitable for those who worked with React already and would like to learn TypeScript and how to use it in a React project.

Regarding the source code that is available for download: you need to install the dependencies using "npm install" before trying to run the source code; the instructions for running the source code are in the lectures.

As always, if you experience a problem with the course or a particular lecture or something is not clear, you can write a question in the Q&A section or send me a message on Udemy.

In the section that follows we're using Create React App(you mentioned a command to create a React app, I guess it’s the command you meant) and Redux. And in the last section we’re working with Next.js (a React framework that includes even more than Create React App, at least at this moment).

In each of these sections, in my opinion, I install the minimal amount of packages necessary for comfortable developer experience. I install each package only at the time when it’s necessary and I explain what that package is used for.

You said: "you spend one hour installing things". In my opinion, this statement is not true. Could you please explain this in more detail?

Finally, even though it’s mentioned in the course description I’d like to say that this course is most suitable for those who worked with React already and would like to learn TypeScript and how to use it in a React project.

Regarding the source code that is available for download: you need to install the dependencies using "npm install" before trying to run the source code; the instructions for running the source code are in the lectures.

As always, if you experience a problem with the course or a particular lecture or something is not clear, you can write a question in the Q&A section or send me a message on Udemy.

response.content:
Thank you Dan for your review. I’m sorry to hear about your experience. Since your review I’ve been working on improving the guidance around this course. I added an introduction article to each section (mentioning prerequisites, listing the links to the code, giving tips around navigating the section, etc.), fixed a few links to the code examples, added more descriptive readme files to the source code folders to make it easier to browse, and other improvements. Also, you can find the links to the source code related to a lecture in its Resources list.

Can anything be added or changed in the course to make it better for you?

Remember, if you are unsatisfied with the course, there is the 30-day money-back guarantee, if you’re interested, please check the Udemy’s policy about it.

Best regards,
Dmytro.

Most of the lectures include the links to the related source code. response.content:
Hi Ali! Thanks for your feedback! I'll take it into account when recording the videos.

Nevertheless, I’d like to explain the logic behind some of the lectures. In your review you didn’t mention particular cases where some components weren’t explained enough, so my explanation might not directly relate to your experience.

In some lectures I don’t type the code of some components in the video, but introduce them explaining their code and what they do. For example, in the lecture from the "TypeScript" section called "Implementing Interfaces" (which is available in the course preview) I introduce some code in the beginning instead of typing it in the video. I use the same technique to introduce the "CreateTaskForm" component in the lecture called "Create Task Form" from the "Building the Tasks App" section. Basically, I describe the purpose of the component, show its initial code and where it’s being rendered. The course is targeted primarily on the learners who have experience working with React, so in order to save precious time I decided not to code some boilerplate stuff directly in the video, but instead introduce it in the beginning and focus on coding more advanced things.

results.content: He's just not a great teacher and it seems like he reads out definitions or from a book, without thinking through the context of his students. The target group are obviously people who know JS. And yet, in the beginning he explains what modules are (just regular ES6 modules!), or he'll explain what an array is.. and time and time again I feel like he's just reading out definitions rather than drawing from actual teaching experience and an understanding of where his students might be at. It's not horrible, but my time is too precious for mediocre (at best) content.

Overall, great course!

results.content:
Great course about TypeScript in React world with a nice working example.

One thing that could be improved: the videos showing the code is using a really big font so not really able to see more code to understand the context he is speaking about, and maybe spend more time on the code you are talking about: to fast typing and moving away from code, doing a lot of play/stop/rewind to understand sometimes :)

response.content: Andrei, thank you very much for your review. I'll take your suggestion about the font into account while recording new videos and updating the old ones.
response.content_html: Andrei, thank you very much for your review. I'll take your suggestion about the font into account while recording new videos and updating the old ones.

results.content: Great tutorial! Lots of description of why you do things. Also very quick and thorough in answering any questions. Thanks

response.content: Vaughan, thank you.

results.content_html: Great tutorial! Lots of description of why you do things. Also very quick and thorough in answering any questions. Thanks

results.content:
The course is extremely fast, too fast to be honest. Its more like a 'how-to' video series, because the explanation is very poor, and its just "lets do this, and then this and then we do this..etc". 
But in the end, you will learn much. It provided some value for me and I learnt something. So I give 3 stars.
To the lecturer: If you want to make really good education courses, have a look at Andrew Mead's Courses (https://mead.io/). They are really super well structured and the speed is good to follow.

results.content:
I didn't like the teaching method, you start coding without any sort of presentation (expect the Apollo parts). 

It's very confusing for me to understand your code and the things you trying to teach while you are coding.

Definitely not easy for a junior developer with the required experience, I'd recommend this course only for experienced Typescript & React developers to get some additional experience

Дружище! Спасибо тебе за твой курс! 
Я так долго искал по всему интернету грамотное толковое объяснение взаимодействие тс и реакта, и нашел!

results.content:
A solid course overall.
In my opinion, some examples are too abstract. Having a real-life use case would be better. 
Part of the course is dedicated to newer features of React, e.g. hooks. While the explanations are good, it is outside the scope of the course. The subject of hooks in the context of TS is barely touched.
results.content_html:
